author: Maarten Menheere
title: Paper wallet terminal for in a shop
description: People need a way to transfer fiat currency to ADA when they don't have access to a phone, electricity or bank account.

assessments.note: The idea is good, but it is not new. Similar products already exist. According to the author of the proposal, this idea would help to spread ADA in Africa, which is related to the objectives of the challenge. The author also says that part of the transaction carried out there would remain as a fee for the store, but it is not known who owns it: an African in fact, or it could be a multinational franchise, for example. "The customer would go into the store and have heard about ADA somewhere," which is a problem, given that it is known that this subject still has little scope on the continent. The ideal would be to ensure that stores that have a possible local machine, and that there is, at the same time, a process of disseminating information on the subject. As I understand it, the only African explicitly in the project would be the shopkeeper himself, which the project specifies as someone who understands the technology of cryptocurrencies. And this would need training, which would be another benefit for the community, after all one of its members encompassing the universe of finance and technologies. However, proposals must seek to be plural, to reach the maximum number of people possible. The beneficiaries here before, bulletin, the store that owns the machine, the shopkeeper and the team involved in the manufacture of the technology. It is necessary to expand this network.
People will go to shops and see the terminal. It will give an option in the physical world and might help the adoption speed up.

This project addresses variations of user conditions and integrates physical objects and unique interface considerations relevant to the community. The interface also addresses needs when power grids are interrupted. It opens many doors which could be expanded for more resilient physical forms or materials for interface. These could include materials which the community is familiar with, in terms of history and tactile familiarity. It is important to consider, especially at this early stage, how we connect the human body with diverse locations and histories, to the blockchain.

I give a 5 for impact because the concept is simple, spelled out, and definitely addresses the question of expanding Cardano in Africa. The proposal tells us that there is a lack of technological access in Africa but that should not stop people from acquiring ADA as an asset. The machine this proposer seeks to build will allow for Africans to access the ADA currency without having a computer or cell phone. There are metrics for the project and it can clearly scale beyond the prototyping and initial build outlined here.

The author of the proposal claims to be an industrial designer, with a master's degree, and to have 8 years of experience building machines, knowing something about programming and systems. But, apparently, he does not have previous experience with the continent or with the training of people (the shopkeeper would need to be well educated), which are important points to be considered as well. It is necessary to increase the range of skills, not discarding the technical part, but adding it with other factors.
Nice pictures, embedded in the story of Cardano and showing that there is already put effort in the project. Known track record on engineering.

I give a 5 for feasability because the proposer provides a clear and managable timeline along with images and flowcharts for the project. They know exactly what needs to be done and how much time it will take them. They explain the technology and resources needed for the project. Budget is provided.

To meet the challenge I would suggest this plan should be bolder. Rather than just building 5 prototypes, add a plan to deliver a larger number of devices, education and marking to get it into stores, and some details on the ongoing funding situation. Would the terminals charge a small fee per transaction which would then be used to build and distribute more machines?
assessments.reply: To me it is obvious I will not stop applying for consecutive funds. There are a large number of future possilibiies. Being bolder is no justification for such a low score.

assessments.note: Here is a step by step of how the project would happen, making it very clear how this process takes place, as well as some production costs and possible release dates for the prototypes. It is possible to know the total amount of investment requested, of course, but it is not whether the project would need more money to keep going. Many technical details about the wallet machine are provided, including a video of 13 explaining the mechanisms of its operation, which serves to increase the credibility of the product. There is also attached a website in Dutch explaining some technology projects, but few people speak Dutch, this website confuses readers and fails to be informative.

I believe in the idea because I think it's gives more options to people and even without using it in the start (it will actually, depending on the software have many options of use) by the customer it will help to get used with the idea. It will also gives some practical solutions and opportunities for people to get a wallet.
Cardano developers are already preparing for this type of interface and integration.
The KPIs are simple but completely match with the project as needed. The roadmap and milestones are clear and they target the problem. This machine itself could be audited for success.

solution: A terminal at a shop where a customer can give the shop owner paper money. The customer gets an ADA wallet with the deposited amount
experience: Industrial designer (TU Delft masters). 8 years experience in building change machines and POS systems. Some programming experience
